comment_text.mn31:1.1: This discourse is a favorite among monastics, depicting an ideal life of simplicity and friendship. The introduction recurs at Kd 10:4.2.1 and, with a different teaching portion, at MN 128:81. In both those cases it is set after the Buddha left the quarreling monks of Kosambī. | This discourse and MN 128 appear to be influenced by Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.3, a famous dialogue where an unusually reluctant Yājñavalkya is repeatedly pressed by King Janaka to reveal the true nature of a person’s light. At SN 7.9:14.4 this passage is alluded to directly.
comment_text.mn31:1.2: Ñātika (also spelled nātika, or nādika; Sanskrit jñātṛka; Prākrit nāyika) was the clan to which the Jain leader Mahāvīra (called Nāṭaputta, i.e. Ñātiputta) belonged. This is the chief town of the clan. It was part of the Vajjian Federation (See DN 16:2.5.1). | Over a millennium previously, the Indus Valley Civilization had built cities of fired brick with standardized size and construction methods, but in the Buddha’s day most buildings were wood. This is the only brick building mentioned in the suttas, although brick construction is also discussed in the Vinaya.
comment_text.mn31:2.1: Anuruddha was the brother of Ānanda and Mahānāma (Kd 17:1.1.3) which, according to the commentary, makes the Buddha his cousin. He was an exponent of mindfulness meditation (SN 52.1, etc.) and master of clairvoyance (AN 1.192:1.1. | Kimbila was one of the seven leading Sakyans, including Anuruddha and Ānanda, who went forth together (Kd 17:1.4.1). | Several Nandiyas are known in the suttas, one of whom was a Sakyan (SN 55.40, AN 11.13; the root nand (“joy”) was a popular choice for Sakyan names: Ānanda, Nanda, Upananda). While Nandiya is not mentioned as having gone forth with the seven, Kimbila refers to their group as the “Sakyan friends” in his verses at Thag 2.18, so it seems likely he was indeed the Sakyan Nandiya; perhaps he went forth later than his friends.
comment_text.mn31:3.2: This is one of several instances showing that the Buddha looked like an ordinary ascetic (see also DN 2:11.2, MN 140:5.11).
comment_text.mn31:3.5: Attakāmarūpa is glossed by the commentary as “those whose nature is to desire their own welfare”. In the Vinaya (attakāma) means to serve “one’s own desires” (Bu Ss 4). But here it draws on Yājnavalkya’s description of one whose form is such that, having attained their only desire, the Self, they have become without desire (ātmakāmam āptakāmam akāmaṁ rūpaṁ, Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 14.7.1.21, Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.3.21. Cf. niṣkāma āptakāma ātmakāmo, Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 14.7.2.8, Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.4.6. In both cases the Bṛhadāraṇyaka reverses the sequence of āpta … ātma.) This describes a sage who is fully immersed in the realization of Brahman in death or dreamless sleep. Such realization is a form of “knowledge” (veda). Here the suffix -rūpa does not mean “seemingly”, nor is it to be discarded as a mere idiom, but has the sense given in the commentary, a person’s true form or true nature (sabhāva). This is, of course, not a Buddhist concept. But it is spoken by the keeper of a park (not a monastery) who fails to even recognize the Buddha. There is no reason he should be Buddhist. To this day, Buddhist monastics are received with kindness and unhesitatingly supported by Hindus, who readily interpret and describe the monastics’ practice in their own terms.
comment_text.mn31:5.7: The text refers to “Anuruddhas” in plural, referring to the group via their most senior member.
comment_text.mn31:6.1: The emphasis on harmonious living fits the accounts in Kd 10:4.2.1 and MN 128, where the Buddha had just left the quarreling community of Kosambī. This suggests that the introduction belongs there, when the three friends were practicing together in the Eastern Bamboo Park near Kosambī. The current sutta is set around 400 kms to the east near Vesālī, and it is hardly likely that the Buddha went straight there after leaving Kosambī. In addition, in MN 128 the three friends are still developing their meditation, whereas in the current sutta they have already achieved arahantship. Also, the location there is said to be the site of a hall for Vedic rituals, which suits the evidently non-Buddhist park keeper. It seems that the popular introduction of MN 128 was reused to frame a later conversation with the three friends, despite the implausibility of the same events happening in the same way twice.
comment_text.mn31:7.4: These are three of the six “warm-hearted qualities” of MN 48:6.2 and AN 6.11:1.1.
comment_text.mn31:8.2: Normally I render viharati in such instances as “meditate”. But Anuruddha’s response avoids talking about meditation. I think he is deliberately avoiding the topic, skirting the obvious intended meaning by seizing on an ambiguity. His reticence echoes Yājñavalkya’s reticence to answer Janaka on the topic of a person’s light (Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.3.1).
comment_text.mn31:9.7: For hatthavilaṅghaka (“lending a hand up”) see MN 125:9.2. | The Chinese parallels (MA 128 at T i 729c9 and EA 24.8 at T ii 629a23) both add that they then retire for meditation.
comment_text.mn31:9.8: That is, three times in each uposatha period lasting a fortnight. | The Chinese parallels add that they might also sit in noble silence (in accord with MN 26:4.13).
comment_text.mn31:9.9: Here the Vinaya account ends, as it is concerned with the settlement of the quarrel among the monks of Kosambī.
comment_text.mn31:10.4: The first absorption is defined at Bu Pj 4:4.1.3.1 as the most basic “superhuman distinction”. Thus Anuruddha is answering the question directly but humbly, revealing as little as possible.
comment_text.mn31:11-13.2: Samatikkamāya (“for going beyond”) is used in a similar sense at MN 10:47.1.
comment_text.mn31:20.3: Even such close monks did not reveal their attainments to each other, a testament to their character. This is a reminder of the virtue of discretion when speaking of such subtle matters. They are not things to be bandied about in common conversation.
comment_text.mn31:21.1: Parajana means “stranger” (Mil 6.3.1:13.2) or “strange spirit” (MN 25:5.20). The commentary identifies him with the Dīgha of DN 32:10.18. He must have been the deity of a local shrine. This passage shows how the intercession of even such a humble spirit can resound among all the gods.
comment_text.mn31:21.2: The praise that follows is unusually effusive and can be compared with the equally unusual recounting of the enlightened devotees of Ñātika (DN 16:2.5.1). Both passages serve to extol Buddhism in the home of Mahāvīra, the Buddha’s elder rival.

root_text.mn31:2.1: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā ca anuruddho āyasmā ca nandiyo āyasmā ca kimilo gosiṅgasālavanadāye viharanti.
root_text.mn31:3.1: Atha kho bhagavā sāyanhasamayaṁ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yena gosiṅgasālavanadāyo tenupasaṅkami.
root_text.mn31:3.2: Addasā kho dāyapālo bhagavantaṁ dūratova āgacchantaṁ.
root_text.mn31:4.1: Assosi kho āyasmā anuruddho dāyapālassa bhagavatā saddhiṁ mantayamānassa.
root_text.mn31:4.5: Atha kho āyasmā anuruddho yenāyasmā ca nandiyo āyasmā ca kimilo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantañca nandiyaṁ āyasmantañca kimilaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn31:5.1: Atha kho āyasmā ca anuruddho āyasmā ca nandiyo āyasmā ca kimilo bhagavantaṁ paccuggantvā—
root_text.mn31:5.2: eko bhagavato pattacīvaraṁ paṭiggahesi, eko āsanaṁ paññapesi, eko pādodakaṁ upaṭṭhāpesi.
root_text.mn31:5.5: Tepi kho āyasmanto bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu.
root_text.mn31:5.6: Ekamantaṁ nisinnaṁ kho āyasmantaṁ anuruddhaṁ bhagavā etadavoca:
root_text.mn31:5.7: “Kacci vo, anuruddhā, khamanīyaṁ, kacci yāpanīyaṁ, kacci piṇḍakena na kilamathā”ti?
root_text.mn31:5.8: “Khamanīyaṁ, bhagavā, yāpanīyaṁ, bhagavā; na ca mayaṁ, bhante, piṇḍakena kilamāmā”ti.
root_text.mn31:6.1: “Kacci pana vo, anuruddhā, samaggā sammodamānā avivadamānā khīrodakībhūtā aññamaññaṁ piyacakkhūhi sampassantā viharathā”ti?
root_text.mn31:6.2: “Taggha mayaṁ, bhante, samaggā sammodamānā avivadamānā khīrodakībhūtā aññamaññaṁ piyacakkhūhi sampassantā viharāmā”ti.
root_text.mn31:6.3: “Yathā kathaṁ pana tumhe, anuruddhā, samaggā sammodamānā avivadamānā khīrodakībhūtā aññamaññaṁ piyacakkhūhi sampassantā viharathā”ti?
root_text.mn31:7.4: Tassa mayhaṁ, bhante, imesu āyasmantesu mettaṁ kāyakammaṁ paccupaṭṭhitaṁ āvi ceva raho ca;

root_text.mn31:7.6: mettaṁ manokammaṁ paccupaṭṭhitaṁ āvi ceva raho ca.

root_text.mn31:8.2: Kacci pana vo, anuruddhā, appamattā ātāpino pahitattā viharathā”ti?

root_text.mn31:9.2: “Yathā kathaṁ pana tumhe, anuruddhā, appamattā ātāpino pahitattā viharathā”ti?
root_text.mn31:9.3: “Idha, bhante, amhākaṁ yo paṭhamaṁ gāmato piṇḍāya paṭikkamati so āsanāni paññapeti, pānīyaṁ paribhojanīyaṁ upaṭṭhāpeti, avakkārapātiṁ upaṭṭhāpeti.
root_text.mn31:9.4: Yo pacchā gāmato piṇḍāya paṭikkamati, sace hoti bhuttāvaseso sace ākaṅkhati bhuñjati, no ce ākaṅkhati appaharite vā chaḍḍeti, appāṇake vā udake opilāpeti.
root_text.mn31:9.5: So āsanāni paṭisāmeti, pānīyaṁ paribhojanīyaṁ paṭisāmeti, avakkārapātiṁ paṭisāmeti, bhattaggaṁ sammajjati.
root_text.mn31:9.6: Yo passati pānīyaghaṭaṁ vā paribhojanīyaghaṭaṁ vā vaccaghaṭaṁ vā rittaṁ tucchaṁ so upaṭṭhāpeti.
root_text.mn31:9.7: Sacassa hoti avisayhaṁ, hatthavikārena dutiyaṁ āmantetvā hatthavilaṅghakena upaṭṭhāpema, na tveva mayaṁ, bhante, tappaccayā vācaṁ bhindāma.
root_text.mn31:9.8: Pañcāhikaṁ kho pana mayaṁ, bhante, sabbarattikaṁ dhammiyā kathāya sannisīdāma.
root_text.mn31:9.9: Evaṁ kho mayaṁ, bhante, appamattā ātāpino pahitattā viharāmā”ti.
root_text.mn31:10.2: Atthi pana vo, anuruddhā, evaṁ appamattānaṁ ātāpīnaṁ pahitattānaṁ viharantānaṁ uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanaviseso adhigato phāsuvihāro”ti?
root_text.mn31:10.4: Idha mayaṁ, bhante, yāvadeva ākaṅkhāma vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharāma.
root_text.mn31:10.5: Ayaṁ kho no, bhante, amhākaṁ appamattānaṁ ātāpīnaṁ pahitattānaṁ viharantānaṁ uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanaviseso adhigato phāsuvihāro”ti.
root_text.mn31:11-13.2: Etassa pana vo, anuruddhā, vihārassa samatikkamāya etassa vihārassa paṭippassaddhiyā atthañño uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanaviseso adhigato phāsuvihāro”ti?
root_text.mn31:11-13.4: Idha mayaṁ, bhante, yāvadeva ākaṅkhāma vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā ajjhattaṁ sampasādanaṁ cetaso ekodibhāvaṁ avitakkaṁ avicāraṁ samādhijaṁ pītisukhaṁ dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharāma.
root_text.mn31:11-13.5: Etassa, bhante, vihārassa samatikkamāya etassa vihārassa paṭippassaddhiyā ayamañño uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanaviseso adhigato phāsuvihāro”ti.
root_text.mn31:14.2: Etassa pana vo, anuruddhā, vihārassa samatikkamāya etassa vihārassa paṭippassaddhiyā atthañño uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanaviseso adhigato phāsuvihāro”ti?
root_text.mn31:14.4: Idha mayaṁ, bhante, yāvadeva ākaṅkhāma pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhakā ca viharāma, satā ca sampajānā, sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṁvedema, yaṁ taṁ ariyā ācikkhanti: ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharāma.
root_text.mn31:14.5: Etassa, bhante, vihārassa samatikkamāya etassa vihārassa paṭippassaddhiyā ayamañño uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanaviseso adhigato phāsuvihāro”ti.
root_text.mn31:15.2: Etassa pana vo, anuruddhā, vihārassa samatikkamāya etassa vihārassa paṭippassaddhiyā atthañño uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanaviseso adhigato phāsuvihāro”ti?
root_text.mn31:15.4: Idha mayaṁ, bhante, yāvadeva ākaṅkhāma sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā, pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā, adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharāma.
root_text.mn31:15.5: Etassa, bhante, vihārassa samatikkamāya etassa vihārassa paṭippassaddhiyā ayamañño uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanaviseso adhigato phāsuvihāro”ti.
root_text.mn31:16.2: Etassa pana vo, anuruddhā, vihārassa samatikkamāya etassa vihārassa paṭippassaddhiyā atthañño uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanaviseso adhigato phāsuvihāro”ti?

root_text.mn31:19.1: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantañca anuruddhaṁ āyasmantañca nandiyaṁ āyasmantañca kimilaṁ dhammiyā kathāya sandassetvā samādapetvā samuttejetvā sampahaṁsetvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmi.

root_text.mn31:20.3: ‘imāsañca imāsañca vihārasamāpattīnaṁ mayaṁ lābhino’ti, yaṁ no āyasmā anuruddho bhagavato sammukhā yāva āsavānaṁ khayā pakāsetī”ti?

root_text.mn31:21.1: Atha kho dīgho parajano yakkho yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṁ ṭhito kho dīgho parajano yakkho bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:

root_text.mn31:22.2: Yasmāpi, dīgha, kulā ete tayo kulaputtā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajitā, tañcepi kulaṁ ete tayo kulaputte pasannacittaṁ anussareyya, tassapāssa kulassa dīgharattaṁ hitāya sukhāya.

root_text.mn31:22.4: Yasmāpi, dīgha, gāmā ete tayo kulaputtā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajitā, so cepi gāmo ete tayo kulaputte pasannacitto anussareyya, tassapāssa gāmassa dīgharattaṁ hitāya sukhāya.
root_text.mn31:22.5: Yasmāpi, dīgha, nigamā ete tayo kulaputtā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajitā, so cepi nigamo ete tayo kulaputte pasannacitto anussareyya, tassapāssa nigamassa dīgharattaṁ hitāya sukhāya.
root_text.mn31:22.6: Yasmāpi, dīgha, nagarā ete tayo kulaputtā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajitā, tañcepi nagaraṁ ete tayo kulaputte pasannacittaṁ anussareyya, tassapāssa nagarassa dīgharattaṁ hitāya sukhāya.
root_text.mn31:22.7: Yasmāpi, dīgha, janapadā ete tayo kulaputtā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajitā, so cepi janapado ete tayo kulaputte pasannacitto anussareyya, tassapāssa janapadassa dīgharattaṁ hitāya sukhāya.
root_text.mn31:22.8: Sabbe cepi, dīgha, khattiyā ete tayo kulaputte pasannacittā anussareyyuṁ, sabbesānampāssa khattiyānaṁ dīgharattaṁ hitāya sukhāya.
root_text.mn31:22.11: sabbe cepi, dīgha, suddā ete tayo kulaputte pasannacittā anussareyyuṁ, sabbesānampāssa suddānaṁ dīgharattaṁ hitāya sukhāya.
root_text.mn31:22.12: Sadevako cepi, dīgha, loko samārako sabrahmako sassamaṇabrāhmaṇī pajā sadevamanussā ete tayo kulaputte pasannacittā anussareyya, sadevakassapāssa lokassa samārakassa sabrahmakassa sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya dīgharattaṁ hitāya sukhāya.
root_text.mn31:22.13: Passa, dīgha, yāva ete tayo kulaputtā bahujanahitāya paṭipannā bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya, atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānan”ti.
root_text.mn31:22.15: Attamano dīgho parajano yakkho bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandīti.

translation_text.mn31:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying at Ñātika in the brick house.
translation_text.mn31:2.1: Now at that time the venerables Anuruddha, Nandiya, and Kimbila were staying in the sal forest park at Gosiṅga.
translation_text.mn31:3.1: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and went to that park.
translation_text.mn31:3.2: The park keeper saw the Buddha coming off in the distance
translation_text.mn31:3.5: There are three gentlemen staying here whose nature is to desire self-knowledge.
translation_text.mn31:4.1: Anuruddha heard the park keeper conversing with the Buddha,
translation_text.mn31:4.3: “Don’t keep the Buddha out, good park keeper!
translation_text.mn31:4.4: Our Teacher, the Blessed One, has arrived.”
translation_text.mn31:4.5: Then Anuruddha went to Nandiya and Kimbila, and said to them,
translation_text.mn31:4.6: “Come forth, venerables, come forth! Our Teacher, the Blessed One, has arrived!”
translation_text.mn31:5.1: Then Anuruddha, Nandiya, and Kimbila came out to greet the Buddha.
translation_text.mn31:5.2: One received his bowl and robe, one spread out a seat, and one set out water for washing his feet.
translation_text.mn31:5.3: The Buddha sat on the seat spread out,
translation_text.mn31:5.5: Those venerables bowed and sat down to one side.
translation_text.mn31:5.7: “I hope you’re keeping well, Anuruddha and friends; I hope you’re all right. And I hope you’re having no trouble getting almsfood.”
translation_text.mn31:5.8: “We’re keeping well, Blessed One, we’re getting by. And we have no trouble getting almsfood.”
translation_text.mn31:6.1: “I hope you’re living in harmony, appreciating each other, without quarreling, blending like milk and water, and regarding each other with kindly eyes?”
translation_text.mn31:6.2: “Indeed, sir, we live in harmony like this.”
translation_text.mn31:6.3: “But how do you live this way?”
translation_text.mn31:7.3: to live together with spiritual companions such as these.’
translation_text.mn31:7.4: I consistently treat these venerables with kindness by way of body, speech, and mind, both in public and in private.
translation_text.mn31:7.8: ‘Why don’t I set aside my own ideas and just go along with these venerables’ ideas?’
translation_text.mn31:7.10: Though we’re different in body, sir, we’re one in mind, it seems to me.”
translation_text.mn31:7.11: And the venerables Nandiya and Kimbila spoke likewise, and they added:
translation_text.mn31:7.23: “That’s how we live in harmony, appreciating each other, without quarreling, blending like milk and water, and regarding each other with kindly eyes.”
translation_text.mn31:8.2: But I hope you’re living diligently, keen, and resolute?”
translation_text.mn31:9.2: “But how do you live this way?”
translation_text.mn31:9.3: “In this case, sir, whoever returns first from almsround prepares the seats, and puts out the drinking water and the rubbish bin.
translation_text.mn31:9.4: If there’s anything left over, whoever returns last eats it if they like. Otherwise they throw it out where there is little that grows, or drop it into water that has no living creatures.
translation_text.mn31:9.5: Then they put away the seats, drinking water, and rubbish bin, and sweep the refectory.
translation_text.mn31:9.6: If someone sees that the pot of water for washing, drinking, or the toilet is empty they set it up.
translation_text.mn31:9.7: If he can’t do it, he summons another with a wave of the hand, and they set it up by lending each other a hand to lift. But we don’t break into speech for that reason.
translation_text.mn31:9.8: And every five days we sit together for the whole night and discuss the teachings.
translation_text.mn31:9.9: That’s how we live diligently, keen, and resolute.”
translation_text.mn31:10.2: But as you live diligently like this, have you achieved any superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones, a comfortable meditation?”
translation_text.mn31:10.4: Whenever we want, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, we enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.mn31:10.5: This is a superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones, a comfortable meditation, that we have achieved while living diligent, keen, and resolute.”
translation_text.mn31:11-13.2: But have you achieved any other superhuman distinction for going beyond and stilling that meditation?”
translation_text.mn31:11-13.4: Whenever we want, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, we enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.mn31:11-13.5: This is another superhuman distinction that we have achieved for going beyond and stilling that meditation.”
translation_text.mn31:14.2: But have you achieved any other superhuman distinction for going beyond and stilling that meditation?”
translation_text.mn31:14.4: Whenever we want, with the fading away of rapture, we enter and remain in the third absorption, where we meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
translation_text.mn31:14.5: This is another superhuman distinction that we have achieved for going beyond and stilling that meditation.”
translation_text.mn31:15.2: But have you achieved any other superhuman distinction for going beyond and stilling that meditation?”
translation_text.mn31:15.4: Whenever we want, with the giving up of pleasure and pain, and the ending of former happiness and sadness, we enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
translation_text.mn31:15.5: This is another superhuman distinction that we have achieved for going beyond and stilling that meditation.”
translation_text.mn31:16.2: But have you achieved any other superhuman distinction for going beyond and stilling that meditation?”
translation_text.mn31:16.4: Whenever we want, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, we enter and remain in the dimension of infinite space.
translation_text.mn31:16.5: This is another superhuman distinction that we have achieved for going beyond and stilling that meditation.”
translation_text.mn31:17.2: But have you achieved any other superhuman distinction for going beyond and stilling that meditation?”
translation_text.mn31:17.4: Whenever we want, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, we enter and remain in the dimension of infinite consciousness. …
translation_text.mn31:17.5: going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, we enter and remain in the dimension of nothingness. …
translation_text.mn31:17.6: going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, we enter and remain in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.
translation_text.mn31:17.7: This is another superhuman distinction that we have achieved for going beyond and stilling that meditation.”
translation_text.mn31:18.2: But have you achieved any other superhuman distinction for going beyond and stilling that meditation?”
translation_text.mn31:18.4: Whenever we want, going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, we enter and remain in the cessation of perception and feeling. And, having seen with wisdom, our defilements have come to an end.
translation_text.mn31:18.5: This is another superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones, a comfortable meditation, that we have achieved for going beyond and stilling that meditation.
translation_text.mn31:18.6: And we don’t see any better or finer way of meditating comfortably than this.”
translation_text.mn31:18.8: There is no better or finer way of meditating comfortably than this.”
translation_text.mn31:19.1: Then the Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired the venerables Anuruddha, Nandiya, and Kimbila with a Dhamma talk, after which he got up from his seat and left.
translation_text.mn31:20.1: The venerables then accompanied the Buddha for a little way before turning back. Nandiya and Kimbila said to Anuruddha,
translation_text.mn31:20.2: “Did we ever tell you that we had
translation_text.mn31:20.3: gained such and such meditations and attainments, up to the ending of defilements, as you revealed to the Buddha?”
translation_text.mn31:20.4: “The venerables did not tell me that they had
translation_text.mn31:20.5: gained such meditations and attainments. But I discovered it by encompassing your minds,
translation_text.mn31:20.9: I answered when the Buddha directly asked about it.”
translation_text.mn31:21.1: Then the native spirit Dīgha Parajana went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him,
translation_text.mn31:21.2: “The Vajjis are lucky! The Vajjian people are so very lucky
translation_text.mn31:21.3: that the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha stays there, as well as these three gentlemen,
translation_text.mn31:21.4: the venerables Anuruddha, Nandiya, and Kimbila.”
translation_text.mn31:21.5: Hearing the cry of Dīgha Parajana, the earth gods raised the cry …
translation_text.mn31:21.9: Hearing the cry of the earth gods, the gods of the four great kings …
translation_text.mn31:21.13: the gods who love to create …
translation_text.mn31:21.14: the gods who control what is created by others …
translation_text.mn31:21.15: the gods of the Divinity’s host raised the cry,
translation_text.mn31:21.16: “The Vajjis are lucky! The Vajjian people are so very lucky
translation_text.mn31:21.17: that the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha stays there, as well as these three gentlemen,
translation_text.mn31:21.18: the venerables Anuruddha, Nandiya, and Kimbila.”
translation_text.mn31:21.19: And so at that moment, that second, that hour, those venerables were known as far as the realm of divinity.
translation_text.mn31:22.1: “That’s so true, Dīgha! That’s so true!
translation_text.mn31:22.2: If the family from which those three gentlemen went forth from the lay life to homelessness were to recollect those venerables with confident heart, that would be for that family’s lasting welfare and happiness.
translation_text.mn31:22.11: all the workers were to recollect those venerables with confident heart, that would be for all those menials’ lasting welfare and happiness.
translation_text.mn31:22.12: If the whole world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—were to recollect those venerables with confident heart, that would be for the whole world’s lasting welfare and happiness.
translation_text.mn31:22.13: See, Dīgha, how those three gentlemen are practicing for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans!”
translation_text.mn31:22.14: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn31:22.15: Satisfied, the native spirit Dīgha Parajana approved what the Buddha said.

variant_text.mn31:21.19: viditā → saṁviditā (mr) | tena layena → etthantare pāṭho si, sya-all, pts1ed potthakesu
